JBR,

After playing around with it a bit more, there is one more reason to 
like the inner class configuration. While using the junit and 
junitreport tasks in ant I found that you can control whether the 
tests show up as different line items in the report, or all as part 
of the parent. In this way, you junit reports generated by ant can 
be truly "class-based". For those familiar with ant, I use the 
batchtest task to select my test cases based on the class name. All 
classes that end in "Test.class" get run. Therefore, if my inner 
class name ends in Test then in the report you get 
OuterClassTest$InnerTest (establishing a hierarchy in the test 
listing. Otherwise, you can have all of the test methods appear 
under the single OuterClassTest entry by naming the inner classes 
something else. Pretty handy...

Regards,

Josh

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Tharp, Joshua L, SOLGV" 
<jltharp@a...> wrote:
> [JBR]
> ...Agreed, and so using nested classes for related fixtures is not 
a bad
> idea at all. I just don't think that it's necessarily any clearer: 
it's
> just all in one file rather than in three.
> 
> 
> 
>  
> 
> Your points are good, but they seem to boil down to having several
> different classes with good names and all will be right with the 
world.
> While that may be true, the problem I have is more at the package 
scope.
> When looking at a directory, how do you know where to start 
looking? The
> reason I like the inner classes is that you can set up a test 
suite of
> sorts in an obviously named class. With those inner classes, you 
can
> still have several test files that support that main one, but if 
you are
> entering a directory to investigate someone else's testing 
strategy,
> then having a well-defined starting point is a great help. Don't 
get me
> wrong, you can still use several different files, so long as they 
are
> referenced from within an obviously named one. Using your Bag 
examples,
> I would say that the BagTest should refer to the other two, and 
possibly
> a third that actually has the run-of-the-mill type tests. That 
way, when
> entering a directory with tests for 20 or more classes (look at
> java.util for example), I could find BagTest.java quickly and from 
there
> discover the other test classes that are directly applicable.
> 
>  
> 
> Granted, this is all beginning to sound like the student teaching 
the
> teacher, but while I lack some JUnit experience, the software
> engineering experience is there. One of the hardest things about
> approaching a body of source code (production or test) is figuring 
out
> where to start. To that end, it seems having a single, well-named
> starting point makes great strides.
> 
>
